This entire series is helping me review for my finals in college physics! I will continue with this series as I progress into my physics Waves class to get ahead :)

Please do not say "It gets very complicated, very quickly". Rather say, "It will take several or many steps, but none of them are impossible, or even that difficult. Faced with many steps just pace yourself and do not give up."   Please do not say things to elicit feelings of hopelessness. Or to imply that you are much smarter and "only professionals can do this".  Eventually the AIs will have memorized all these things and they will help recall, simulate and calculate the details exactly and precisely.  Using the computer is smart. In work and jobs, getting things done right is often better than memorizing formulas.    Richard Collins, The Internet Foundation

I think charges are surrounded by flux of microscopic particles. Flux of like charges add up while Flux of opposite charges relocates. On closing  a DC circuit electric flux  in the conductor relocates by  exiting   the conductor radially due to opposite charges on both ends of conductor. This establishes an electric field in the conductor which exerts force on charges. This force moves only electrons as they are lighter & loosely attached at the surface of conductor. This establishes  current in the conductor. After initial increase the electric field becomes constant at which flux leaving the conductor stops. Initially moving & changing electric flux induces circulating & changing magnetic flux around the conductor. As electric flux stops, motion of magnetic flux also stop. On achieving equilibrium electric field inside conductor and current flow becomes constant and a circular static magnetic flux of constant density is established around the conductor.

Great video! But you got the second hand rule wrong. 7:10 You should point your hand (I prefer index finger) to the direction of CHARGE VELOCITY and not to the current flow direction. This way your example with two wires will make sense.

With first hand rule you need to point your thumb to the direction of "conventional" current flow (from + to -). With the second hand rule you need to point to direction of CHARGE VELOCITY, so in this case electrons flow direction (from - to +). Isn't it better to describe it as a line integral instead of some simplification of the dot product? You can then see what you're really doing, "adding up" all the parts of the magnetic field through the surface. It makes much more intuitive sense that way, if we "add up" all the magnetic field around the curve, we get the enclosed current times mu-naught.

Minute 5:19. I was very confused about the pink force file and how it is related to the yellow field lines.  After minutes of hard thinking I found it out. The space between the two wires is important as well as the direction of the yellow field lines in between. If the field lines of the two wires point against each other (parallel current) then getting closer together reduces the area where the yellow field lines point straight against each other.   So reducing the amount of field lines in completely different directions is the goal of the two happy wires.

Great video, However describing amperes law as a line integral helps explain the fundamental logic behind the law in a more wider way. I understand though why they did'nt do this in the video as it demands more advanced knowledge of vectorcalculus than a 8 minute video can provide.   talking about the B-field in terms of a vectorfield (a function that in a point P maps a direction and a magnitude of that direction instead of normal "scalar" function that only gives a value Y in point P) gives a more complete picture on the subject. A line integral sums all contributions of the B-field  along a line L (sums the magnitude of all mapped points along the line, that is parallell to the line) . If you close that line creating a loop you have amperes law. You can shape this loop however you want the; law still stands as long as the B-field is defined along the entire loop.   One conclusion you can also draw from this integral is that of the non-existence of magnetic monopoles. One of the most fundamental laws of electromagnetism says that there is no such thing. If you create a small sphere somewhere along the created loop and say that this sphere, because it is close to a source of magnetic flow, must have a flow through it. if you calculate this magnetic flow (also called flux) you will always get 0. This essentially means that as much flux that flowed into the sphere also flows out summing it to 0. This does not mean however that the line integral will always be zero.   The opposite of this would be the electric field. There is such a thing as an electric monopole for example a point charge. The electric field will be directed outwards in every direction from this point charge which means that if you create a sphere around the point charge and sum all electric flow through it you will get a non-zero answer, in fact you will get total charge inside that sphere. This is called the gauss law for electric fields and is essentially the electro version of the amperes law.   Because of the point charge and the fact that the electric field is directed outwards around it, a really cool conclusion can be made. If you create a loop around a point charge and perform a line integral around it you will always get zero because The field will always be perpendicular to the line or if it isn't, the non-zero contributions will be neutralized by the equal negative contributions somewhere else on the line. If you "un-close" the loop however you have the formula for electric potential also known as voltage. Today I learned precious little about mathematics, but I did learn:  1. Magnetic force causes wires to torque when a current is put through it. 2. The math behind this action is known as Ampere's Law. 3. The Right-Hand Rules are mnemonic devices created to help consistently identify the direction of magnetic forces. 4. The torque generated by these forces are the basis behind electric motors.  So I didn't understand all of it, but what I did understand was valuable.

​ CrashCourse  the illustration isn't necessarily wrong, it just doesn't describe the direction of the current. the conceptualization still matches the illustration, although with the speed these videos tend to move, it took me some time to see this. Please annotate! It also might be useful to show how the magnetic fields of same direction currents create a destructive interference directly between the wires, which reveals a new general magnetic field superposition (?) analogous to sigma orbitals forming a pi bond. The destructive interference between the two wires, aka the loss of net force at the transversal magnetic field lines between the wires allows the remaining forces surrounding both wires to magnetize(?) or "squish" the wires together. I'm just a student, someone should correct me if i'm wrong.

​ @crashcourse  ​ CrashCourse  the illustration isn't necessarily wrong, it just doesn't describe the direction of the current. the conceptualization still matches the illustration, although with the speed these videos tend to move, it took me some time to see this. Please annotate! It also might be useful to show how the magnetic fields of same direction currents create a destructive interference directly between the wires, which reveals a new general magnetic field superposition (?) analogous to the geometry of 2 p orbitals forming a pi bond or the new geometry of solenoid magnetic field lines generated by the construction of a coiled current carrying wire at 6:22. The destructive interference between the two wires, aka the loss of net force at the transversal magnetic field lines between the wires allows the remaining forces surrounding both wires to magnetize(?) or "squish" the wires together. And constructive interference happens for currents flowing in opposite directions. A not-so clean simplified analogy is imagining fitted gears turning smoothly in opposite directions. The forces at the junction (AKA the transversal between the currents) where the gear teeth meet, add together and create a noticeable net repulsive force between the wires. In magnetic fields ALL the magnetic force vectors of both magnetic fields are constructive or destructive where they overlap.  I'm just a student, someone should correct me if i'm wrong.

The field lines are backwards, and the caption would be correct if the field lines were drawn correctly:  The force on the moving charges in the wire on the left will be to the right (the field caused by the wire on the right is out of the board at the position of the left wire, so the force on the charges in the left wire will be to the right).
